question: Investigation of choice for detection and characterization of interstitial lung disease is-

question: A 25-year-old female presents with progressive dyspnea for one year. CXR shows interstitial opacities and spirometry shows an obstructive pattern. What is the diagnosis?
exp: Interstitial lung disease leads to the restrictive pattern on spirometry. However tuberous sclerosis and Lymphangioleiomyomatosis are exceptions and lead to an obstructive pattern. Pulmonary LAM presents in young females with emphysema, recurrent pneumothorax and chylous pleural effusion.

question: Recognized features of asbestosis do not include:
exp: Features of asbestosis include - clubbing, restrictive pulmonary function, calcification of pleura. Egg shell calcification is not seen in asbestosis. Causes of eggshell calcification in CXR: Treated lymphoma: (post-irradiation Hodgkin disease) usually 1-9 years following treatment Coal workers' pneumoconiosis (CWP) Scleroderma Amyloidosis Blastomycosis Silicosis
opb: Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes
opd: Restrictive pattern of ventilatory defect shown by pulmonary function

question: Which subtype of interstitial lung disease is seen in patients with Sjogren syndrome?
exp: Fibrotic NSIP is the most common subtype of ILD seen in patients with Sjogren syndrome. NSIP is also the most common subtype of ILD seen in patients with connective tissue disorders. Usual interstitial pneumonitis is found in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Cryptogenic organising pneumonia has unknown etiology. Acute interstitial pneumonitis/ Hamman rich syndrome presents as ARDS like illness. Ahritis/ ahralgia:- Most common extraglandular manifestation of Sjogren's.

question: Bronchocentric granulomatosis commonly occurs due to?
exp: Bronchocentric Granulomatosis is characterized by peri-bronchial necrotising granulomatous inflammation. It occurs due to: Hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus in patients with asthma. In patients without asthma, rheumatoid ahritis and infections like TB are associated. Immunological reaction to HIV virus leads to lymphocytic interstitial pneumonitis.

question: Conglomerate nodules are found in?
exp: Conglomerate shadows are seen in silicosis. On continued dust exposure, the nodules increase in size and number ultimately covering most pas of the lungs. With coalescence of the nodules, the upper lobes become fibrotic and contract making the conglomerate nodules to migrate towards the hilar areas. CXR findings in Silicosis:- Snow storm appearance of lung fields. Hilar lymphadenopathy Crazy paving pattern on HRCT. Egg-shell calcifications of the lymph nodes is strongly suggestive of silicosis. Nodular opacities can enlarge and coalesce forming conglomerate shadows. Progressive massive fibrosis

question: Which of the following ILD is not associated with smoking?
exp: Cryptogenic Organising pneumonia has unknown etiology and has a predilection for lower lobe of the lung. There are three ILD which are associated with cigarette smoking. 1. DIP (Desquamative interstitial pneumonia) shows the response to smoking cessation and histologically characterized by the accumulation of macrophages in intra-alveolar spaces. 2. Respiratory bronchiolitis is a subset of DIP with cellular infiltrate in respiratory bronchioles. It resolves with cessation of cigarette smoking. 3. Pulmonary Langerhans cell Histiocytosis has the presence of reticular or nodular opacities and upper lobe cysts. That explains the development of pneumothorax. It improves with cessation of cigarette smoking.

question: What is the first investigation to be done for suspected interstitial lung disease patient?
exp: ILD may be first suspected on basis of abnormal CXR. Findings seen are:- 1. Bibasilar reticular pattern. 2. Nodular opacities. 3. Honeycombing. Subsequently HRCT is done for assessment of the extent of disease, mediastinal adenopathy and determining the site for biopsy. Lung biopsy is the most effective method for confirming the diagnosis of ILD. MDCT is used in pulmonary embolism. Hence choice C is ruled out. Spirometry findings show a restrictive pattern but in some cases, the obstructive pattern is seen. Hence choice D is ruled out.

question: Which pattern is seen in pulmonary function tests in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
exp: Pulmonary function tests In PFT, Airway narrowing, lung volume and gas exchange capacity are quantified and compared with normal values adjusted for age, gender, height, etc. Most forms of ILD will show restrictive pattern on PFT. Restrictive deficit TLC(Total lung capacity) Reduced FEV1(Forced expiratory volume in 1 sec) Symmetrically reduced FVC(Forced vital capacity) Reduced DLCO(Diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide) Reduced FEV1/FVC ratio Normal or increased characteristically >0. 7 Approach to pulmonary function test interpretation:
opa: FEV1/FVC ratio increases and DLCO increases
opb: FEV1/FVC ratio increases and DLCO decreases
opc: FEV1/FVC ratio decreases and DLCO decreases
opd: FEV1/FVC ratio decreases and DLCO increases

question: Periodic Acid Schiff (PAS) stain positive intra-alveolar material is seen in?
exp: PAS material in alveoli is accumulated surfactant due to decreased turnover in pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Characterized by dysfunction of alveolar macrophages which results in decreased surfactant clearance The same material may be coughed up by patients and described as chunky gelatinous plugs. Lipoid pneumonia will show fat globules in macrophages.

question: A 35-year-old coal worker presents with difficulty in breathing on exeion for last 2 years. CXR was performed. What does it show?
exp: The CXR of Coal worker patient shows the presence of hyperinflation in lungs with a tubular appearance of the heart. Lungs appear relatively blacker with flattening of the diaphragm on both sides. The heart appears smaller as lungs are hyper-inflated. These findings are suggestive of emphysema.
